awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Unique Window into the Ecology of Cretaceous Forests During the Rise of Angiosperms
awd_abstract_narration:
Flowering plants first appeared approximately 140 million years ago, during the age of dinosaurs. Flowering plants rapidly diversified and spread around the globe and evolved a variety of life forms that added to the ecological complexity of forests. This project investigates a crucial interval of this transition, ~75 million years ago, by studying a series of exceptionally preserved fossil floras from southern New Mexico, which existed under a wet tropical paleoclimate. These studies will provide important insights into forest evolution in tropical climates, the timing and patterns of ecological expansion of flowering plants, the habitats of dinosaurs and early mammals, and the history of vegetation for the western interior of North America. Most of these plant fossils collected this research represent species new to science and can provide important historical records for living lineages. The project provides training for students from diverse backgrounds. It also has several major initiatives for education and public outreach, including the development, testing, and dissemination of lesson plans for science teachers about the rise of flowering plants and modern forests. 

This project will use extensive paleontological field studies, fossil collections, and new quantitative techniques to generate extensive reconstructions of late Campanian forests from fossilized leaves, wood, seeds and fruits. By using newly developed sampling and analytical techniques, these studies will generate reconstructions of the diversity and ecological structure of the paleo forests. The fossil floras are from the Jose Creek Member of the McRae Formation in south-central New Mexico, which was located >200 km inland of the Western Interior Seaway. The diversity and community structure of the fossil forests will be reconstructed using spatial distributions of plant species across the landscape, while the functional ecology of the plants will be reconstructed by measuring traits of leaves, wood, and seeds/fruits that are reflective of life form, physiology, growth rate, and reproductive strategy. This information, when combined with analyses of climatically similar Cretaceous, Cenozoic, and extant floras, will be used to test hypotheses about: 1) the community structure and roles of major clades in Campanian floras; 2) the functional ecology of Cretaceous angiosperms; and 3) how the ecological structure of forests has changed through time in warm-wet climates. The functional trait-based approach used will link extant and paleo-ecology, and have broad applicability to understanding ecological radiations and community turnover following key evolutionary innovations.

por.por_cntn:
During the Cretaceous period, flowering plants rapidly diversified and took on many new roles in land ecosystems, marking the dawn of modern forests.  The timing and patterns of change across landscapes are incompletely known, partly because the plant fossil record is incomplete.  Plant fossils mostly preserve in environments that are in or close to wet areas, creating bias in the sampled communities. Further, fossil floras that regularly preserve most parts of the plant, leaves, woods, and reproductive structures, are rare in the geologic record.

The 76- to 74-million-year-old fossil Jose Creek Flora (JCF), which includes an ecosystem frozen in time by a volcanic ash called Dori's Tuff, is a rare exception. The JCF was located about 200km inland from a sea that cut through the Western Interior of North America during the Cretaceous, and thus contains forest communities that represent inland, rather than coastal or wetland vegetation. The JCF was farther south and grew under warmer (tropical) conditions than most coeval fossil floras from North America. The Dori's Tuff flora is unusually extensive - the fossil-rich volcanic ash deposit can be traced for 1.2 km - and allows us to make a transect through an ancient forest and map the spatial distribution of its inhabitants. Other fossil beds in the JCF flora preserve abundant stumps, logs, and large wood fragments that belong to flowering plants and conifers.  These provide independent evidence on plant stature (e.g., tree), and their tissue structure documents the physiological responses of forest plants to the environment.

The JCF is among the earliest floras to demonstrate ecological dominance of flowering plants across the landscape.  In Dori's Tuff, which was analyzed by the Berkeley research team, they comprise 89% all species and more than 80% of plant cover. The so-called dicot flowering plants were most abundant, but monocots such as palms, gingers, and skunk cabbages were prominent across the understory to midstory.

The wood flora, investigated by the Texas State research team led by Garland Upchurch, indicates that flowering plants were abundant and diverse, and that the JCF vegetation lived under warm equable conditions during a past period of global warming.  The Forest of Giants (FOG) represents a near-stream forest of large dicot trees preserved in place by a flood. FOG dicots are the largest known Cretaceous plant fossils in the world and include trees with characteristics of modern tropical rainforest canopy trees.  This contrasts with previous ideas regarding the stature of Cretaceous flowering plants, which were based on more northerly fossil assemblages from cooler climates.  Growth patterns in JCF woods indicate the absence of hard freezing and little seasonality to plant growth. This is consistent with multiple species of palms known from the wood record. JCF fossil dicot woods and leaves, along with diverse palms, indicate that the vegetation grew under a climate like that of central to southern Florida, but at the latitude of modern-day Denver, Colorado.

Comparisons with fossil floras of similar age demonstrate that the southern Western Interior was more diverse than more northern regions during the Late Cretaceous (100.5-66 million years ago). Species are typically rare, as in modern tropical vegetation.  For dicot woods, most species are known from three or fewer specimens, which with data from the Dori's Tuff flora indicates high spatial heterogeneity in the source vegetation.  The JCF wood flora contains endemic species and records some of the earliest occurrences of plant families that are important in modern tropical vegetation.  It also shows that there was a common wood flora from the southern Western Interior, with overlapping occurrences of species, that was distinct from the wood flora of the northern Western Interior.

This project involved three undergraduate/masters students and one Ph.D. student from Texas State University, plus numerous undergraduate and two Ph.D. students from the University of California, Berkeley. These students were trained in research aspects of fossil collecting and laboratory analysis and presented their research at professional conferences. This body of research has generated three doctoral theses (one at Texas State University, two at the University of California, Berkeley), which will form the basis for additional peer-reviewed publications. Principal Investigator Garland Upchurch, who is now at the University of Colorado, Boulder, is working with Dr. Dori Contreras, a former member of the Berkeley team now at the Perot Museum in Dallas, Texas, to develop a series of murals depicting the Jose Creek flora.
